image.title: World News Headlines, Latest International News, World Breaking News - Times of India

item.title: How billions in dollar, euro notes are entering Russia despite strict global sanctions: Report
item.description: Since the 2022 export prohibition of US and EU banknotes to Russia, about $2.3 billion in dollars and euros were still sent to Russia, indicating ways to bypass sanctions. Data revealed cash shipments primarily from the UAE and Turkey. Despite Moscow's attempts to reduce reliance on hard currencies, foreign cash remains crucial for trade, travel, and savings for many Russians.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Beggar or tourist? Travellers to Gulf under strict scrutiny at airports in Pakistan
item.description: Pakistani authorities increased airport scrutiny due to a rise in beggars posing as tourists traveling to the Middle East. Reports indicated that 90% of detained beggars abroad were of Pakistani origin. Immigration staff have removed passengers from flights, while UAE authorities have begun rejecting visa applications from Pakistanis without sufficient funds to be deemed 'genuine visitors.'
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Will try to bring back Sheikh Hasina if ... : Bangladesh interim government
item.description: Bangladesh's interim government vowed to repatriate former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina if requested by the law ministry. Foreign affairs adviser Touhid Hossain highlighted the need for good relations with India and emphasized balanced international relations. He also mentioned plans for a fair future election under Nobel laureate Mohammed Yunus's leadership.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Kenya cult leader on trial for manslaughter over mass deaths
item.description: The leader of a Kenyan starvation sect, Paul Nthenge Mackenzie, went on trial for manslaughter over the deaths of over 400 followers in the Shakahola Forest Massacre. Mackenzie and 90 other suspects pleaded not guilty. Prosecutors allege he incited followers to starve to 'meet Jesus,' with at least 420 witnesses prepared for the trial.

item.title: Turkey's priority is fulfilling Nato responsibilities, defence minister says
item.description: Turkey assured its commitment to NATO despite pursuing ties with the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation. Defence Minister Yasar Guler clarified that NATO responsibilities remained a priority. Erdogan's efforts for regional normalization include possible talks with Syria's Assad and joint anti-terrorism actions with Iraq. Discussions around acquiring F-16 and Eurofighter jets continue with Western allies.

item.title: Greek wildfires engulf mountain as they approach Greek capital
item.description: Athens faced extreme fire conditions on Mount Pentelicus on Monday, with flames reaching 80 feet high. Lined by a 30-kilometre front, the fires threatened historic sites like Marathon. Strong winds exacerbated the situation, forcing evacuations including a children's hospital. Firefighters and volunteers battled tirelessly amidst record-breaking summer temperatures.

item.title: 700 migrants cross Channel to Britain in small boats
item.description: Over 700 migrants crossed the Channel to Britain on Sunday, marking the highest number since Keir Starmer became Prime Minister. Two migrants died during the crossing, adding to 25 deaths this year. Starmer, who ended a migrant deportation scheme to Rwanda, pledged to dismantle smuggling gangs. Anti-migrant unrest has followed recent violence falsely linked to immigrants.

item.title: 'Am going to do system scaling tests': Musk reveals plan ahead of his interview with Trump
item.description: Former US President Donald Trump announced he would appear for an interview with Elon Musk on Monday night. Musk revealed he would conduct system scaling tests to prepare. Trump's campaign confirmed the 8 pm Eastern timing, describing the interview as significant. Both Trump and Musk have publicly expressed mutual admiration previously.
item.dc:creator: TOI World Desk

item.title: Trump sued for using Isaac Hayes' iconic song 'Hold On' without permission in his rallies
item.description: The family of late soul legend Isaac Hayes filed a lawsuit against Donald Trump for using the song 'Hold On (Iâm Coming)' without permission at his rallies. The lawsuit cites 134 counts of copyright infringement between 2022 and 2024, demanding Trump to cease usage, remove related videos, and pay $3 million in licensing fees by August 2024.

item.title: Hit Ukrainian units 30km into Russian territory, acknowledges Moscow
Fire at cooling tower of Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant
item.description: Kyiv and Moscow traded blame on Sunday after a fire broke out at a cooling tower of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant, under the control of Russian forces. Only Ukrainian control over the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant can guarantee a return to normalcy and complete safety," Zelensky said.
